questions.text: A 50-year-old woman underwent a screening colonoscopy. A single polyp is found, resected, and sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following biopsy findings will have the highest risk of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.

Adenomatous polyps can be tubular, tubulovillous, and villous adenomas. Among these, tubular adenoma has the least risk and villous adenoma has the highest risk of malignancy.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

choices.text: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.solution:
Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential.  

Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature of a hyperplastic polyp.

They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.text: The biopsy of a polyp reported dysplasia up to the colonic submucosa. Classify this lesion using Haggitt's classification:
questions.solution:
According to Haggitt’s classification, a polyp invading the submucosa comes under level 4.

Related Pearl: Haggitt’s classification for polyps containing cancer according to the depth of invasion

  • Level 0: Carcinoma does not invade the muscularis mucosae (carcinoma in situ or intramucosal carcinoma)
  • Level 1: Carcinoma invades through the muscularis mucosae into the submucosa but is limited to the head of the polyp
  • Level 2: Carcinoma invades the level of the neck of the polyp (junction between the head and stalk)
  • Level 3: Carcinoma invades any part of the stalk
  • Level 4: Carcinoma invades into the submucosa of the bowel wall below the stalk of the polyp but above the muscularis propria

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient undergoes a screening colonoscopy after his brother was diagnosed with colorectal cancer. Which of the following, if detected, does not indicate a risk of developing colon cancer?

choices.text: Villous adenomas in the ascending colon
More than 100 polyps in the transverse and descending colon
Inflammatory polyps in the sigmoid colon and rectum
Sessile serrated adenomatous polyps in the sigmoid colon

questions.solution:
Inflammatory polyps are not premalignant.

Inflammatory polyps (pseudopolyps) are found in cases of:

  • Inflammatory bowel disease (most common)
  • Amebic colitis
  • Ischemic colitis
  • Schistosomal colitis

Microscopic examination shows islands of normal, regenerating mucosa (the polyp) surrounded by areas of mucosal loss.

questions.text: A 12-year-old is brought to the emergency with features of intestinal obstruction. An ultrasound reveals a target sign, suggesting intussusception. On closer examination, her palm and oral mucosa are spotted with multiple 1-2 mm blue-gray macules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has Peutz–Jeghers syndrome.

It is characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract (more commonly small intestine) and hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits. In the given clinical scenario, the patient has had an intestinal intussusception. The numerous polyps in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome often serve as a lead point.

Option A: Turcot syndrome constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors (including cerebellar medulloblastoma and glioblastomas)

Option B: Lynch syndrome is also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC). It is due to defective mismatch repair (MMR) of DNA.

Option D: Cowden syndrome is characterized by polyps of the stomach or colon, macrocephaly and benign tumors of thyroid, breast, and uterus.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: Ophthalmoscopy performed on a 14-year-old boy had the given incidental finding. Family history revealed that his grandfather had colon cancer and an aunt was diagnosed with endometrial carcinoma. Genetic testing confirmed APC gene mutation. Which of the following is false about his condition?

choices.text: Condition can be passed on to his daughter in the future
Mutation of APC gene is on chromosome 15

questions.solution:
The given image showing a pigmented retina, the patient's family history and APC gene mutation is suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis. Familial adenomatous polyposis is due to the mutation of APC gene located on the long arm of chromosome 5 (5q21), not 15.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is autosomal dominant. It is characterized by the presence of >100 adenomatous polyps in colon and rectum. It usually manifests by the late 2nd or early 3rd decade. Although it accounts for 1% of all colorectal carcinoma, the risk of development of cancer is 100%.

CHRPE (Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epthelium) is the earliest extra-colonic manifestation of FAP, present in up to 75% of patients. 

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: All of the following are gastrointestinal manifestations seen in patients with FAP except:

choices.text: Fundal gland hyperplasia in gastric polyp

questions.solution:
Esophageal carcinoma is not associated with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is associated with gastric and duodenal polyps in approximately 50% of the affected individuals.

Most of the gastric polyps represent fundic gland hyperplasia and have limited malignant potential. Duodenal polyps are adenomatous in nature and premalignant.

Patients with FAP have an increased risk for duodenal ampullary cancer.

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Gardner's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Gardner’s syndrome does not include brain tumors.

Components of Gardner’s syndrome:

  • Osteomas: most common manifestation, most commonly in the mandible
  • Polyposis colon
  • Dental anomalies (supernumerary tooth, absent tooth, impacted tooth)
  • Epidermal inclusion cysts
  • Desmoid tumors

Note:

Turcot’s syndrome includes brain tumor and colorectal polyps.

Related Pearl: Classification of colorectal polyps

Colorectal polyps can be classified as:

Neoplastic

Adenomatous polyps:

  • Tubular adenoma (Most common)
  • Tubulovillous adenomas
  • Villous adenoma (highest risk of malignancy)

Non-neoplastic:

  • Hyperplastic
  • Hamartomatous
    • Juvenile polyp(solitary)-benign
    • Juvenile polyposis syndromes (multiple)-premalignant
    • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome- occasionally carcinoma may develop.
    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory
    • Pseudopolyp
    • Benign lymphoid polyp

Note:

*Cronkite-Canada syndrome: Cancer occurs in the stomach, colon, and rectum, but it remains controversial whether these polyps  possess malignant potential. As many as 15% of patients with Cronkite- Canada syndrome have a malignant tumor at the time of diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common presentation of abdominal desmoid tumor?
questions.solution:
Explanation: 

The most common presentation of an abdominal desmoid tumor is an abdominal mass. 

Desmoid tumors, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis or desmoid-type fibromatosis are locally aggressive tumors that lack metastatic potential. Desmoid tumors can be sporadic in origin or associated with familial adenomatous polyposis. 

These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage.

The investigation of choice for a desmoid tumor is MRI. It is superior to CT in defining the pattern and the extent of involvement and can determine recurrence after surgery. Diagnosis is established by a biopsy with immunohistochemistry, which stains positive for beta-catenin, actin and vimentin, and negative for desmin, cytokeratin and S-100.

Treatment: 

  • An initial observation is preferred for stable, asymptomatic, primary or recurrent desmoids, especially if surgery can cause high mortality. 
  • Surgical resection with negative margin clearance is reserved for patients with small abdominal wall tumors associated with pain or an increase in size. 
  • Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosinase kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy
  • Radiotherapy is preferred for candidates unfit for surgery, patients refusing surgery and when surgical resection is associated with high morbidity. 

Related Pearl: Desmoid tumor

  • Unencapsulated fibroma arising from musculoaponeurotic structures usually below the umbilicus.
  • Females>males
  • Extraabdominal (65%) > abdominal (25%) > intraabdominal (15%)
  • Associated with FAP (Gardner syndrome)
  • Infiltrates surrounding tissues but no metastasis and no sarcomatous change.
  • Investigation of choice – MRI
  • Treatment:
    • Wide local excision with negative margin
    • More prone for recurrence – treated by surgery and radiotherapy

questions.text: A 29-year-old man was brought to the hospital with a history of headache and vomiting for the past 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. The image of the MRI scan is shown below. Colonoscopy revealed numerous polyps in the colon and the rectum which were found to be adenomatous on biopsy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a tumor in the brain. Therefore the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis.

Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%. 

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA).

Variants of FAP are:

  1. Gardner's syndrome- It is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have
    • Osteomas of the mandible or skull 
    • Epidermal cysts
    • Soft tissue tumors like desmoid tumor
  2. Turcot's syndrome- In addition to the colonic polyps the patients will have central nervous system tumors (primary brain tumors).

Option D: Peutz-Jegher's syndrome is not related to familial adenomatous polyposis. It is an autosomal dominant disease characterized by

  • Pigmentation of the mouth and lips
  • Multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestine.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

    • Cronkite-Canada syndrome*
  • Inflammatory

    • Benign lymphoid polyp

questions.text: Colonoscopy and biopsy on a 35-year-old man revealed hundreds of adenomatous polyps in the entire descending and sigmoid colon. Options for prophylactic surgery are discussed. Which of the following procedures will reduce the occurrence of malignancy the most?

choices.text: Total colectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis
Total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome. To prevent an occurrence of cancer, total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis is the management of choice. This procedure is usually accompanied by resection of the rectal mucosa.

Following surgery, the patient has to be routinely followed up for ileoanal-pouch surveillance. Upper GI endoscopy should also be performed to evaluate for the presence of duodenal adenomas.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was recently diagnosed and treated for an autosomal dominant disorder. The gross specimen of his resected colon is given in the image. What is the initial step in screening his 9-year-old child?

choices.text: Genetic testing for APC gene mutation
Genetic testing for MSH-6 gene mutation
Routine flexible sigmoidoscopy starting from 10 years of age
Routine colonoscopy starting from 10 years of age

questions.solution:
More than 100 colonic polyps are diagnostic of familial adenomatous polyposis syndrome and the initial step in screening the child syndrome is to perform genetic testing for APC gene mutation. 

If screening is positive, flexible sigmoidoscopy or colonoscopy is done annually starting from 10 years of age.

If the APC testing is negative, then the risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in the relative is similar to the general population. The screening can be started from 50 years of age.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about Amsterdam criteria?

choices.text: At least 2 or more first-degree relatives affected
At least one case diagnosed before 50 years of age

questions.solution:
According to the Amsterdam criteria for hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), at least one case should be diagnosed before 50 years of age.

Option A: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 2 (not 3) successive generations should be affected.

Option B: According to the Amsterdam criteria for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC, at least 3 relatives (not 2) with at least one being first-degree relatives should be affected.

Related Pearl: Amsterdam Criteria II - Revised Criteria for HNPCC

The diagnostic criteria for HNPCC are referred to as the Amsterdam criteria or the 3-2-1-0 rule.

It includes the following:

  • Three or more relatives with HNPCC-associated cancer (colorectal cancer, endometrial cancer, cancer of the small bowel, ureter, or renal pelvis), one of whom is a first-degree relative of the other two
  • At least two successive generations affected
  • At least one case diagnosed before the age of 50 years
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis excluded.
  • Tumors verified by pathologic examination.

All of the above must be applicable for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC to be made in a family.

questions.text: What is the most common extra-colonic cancer in patients with a mutation in MMR genes?
questions.solution:
Endometrial carcinoma is the most common extracolonic carcinoma in patients with mutated MMR genes.

Autosomal dominant mutation in DNA mismatch repair (MMR) genes, such as hMLH1, hMSH2, hMSH6, PMS1, and PMS2 lead to various cancers. This condition is known as Lynch Syndrome/HNPCC.

Gastric and ovarian carcinoma are also commonly found. 

Related Pearl: Types of Lynch syndromes

  • Lynch I syndrome is characterized by cancer of the proximal colon occurring at a relatively young age.
  • Lynch II syndrome is characterized by fami­lies at risk for both colorectal and extracolonic cancers, including cancers of endometrial, ovarian, gastric, small intestinal, pancre­atic, and ureteral and renal pelvic origin.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about colorectal carcinoma in HNPCC?

choices.text: The onset of cancer occurs early
The progression of the carcinoma is slow
Mucinous adenocarcinoma is the most common type
Tumors predominantly develop in right sided colon

questions.solution:
In hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), there is accelerated tumor progression and normal tumor initiation.

Accelerated tumor initiation is seen in familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

In Hereditary Non-polyposis Colorectal Cancer (HNPCC), the onset of cancer is at a relatively young age (mean, 44 years). Proximal distribution is more common and nearly 70% of cancers are located in the right colon. Mucinous or poorly differentiated (signet cell) adenocarcinoma predominate. There is an increased number of synchronous and metachronous cancers. The outcome after surgery is relatively good.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the dermatologist's office with multiple small bumps on his forehead. Excisional biopsy findings are suggestive of multiple small sebaceous adenomas. Detailed family history reveals that his grandfather and brother have colon cancer while his aunt was diagnosed with rectal cancer. Which syndrome should be suspected?
questions.solution:
Multiple cutaneous sebaceous adenomas and a family history of various cancers are seen in Muir–Torre syndrome.

Muir–Torre variant of hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) may have:

  • Sebaceous adenomas
  • Keratoacanthomas
  • Sebaceous epitheliomas
  • Basal cell epitheliomas

questions.text: Which criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability (MSI) testing?
questions.solution:
Bethesda criteria is used to select patients for microsatellite instability testing. 

Microsatellites are regions of repeated DNA that change in length (show instability) when mismatch repair is not functioning. Defects in mismatch repair genes (as in Lynch syndrome/HNPCC) leads to microsatellite instability. 

Amsterdam criteria is used for a presumptive diagnosis of HNPCC in a family. Because the Amsterdam criteria do not include some patients with known germline MMR gene mutations, another set of guidelines, known as the Bethesda guidelines, was established to help decide whether or not a patient should undergo further molecular testing to rule out HNPCC.

questions.text: In which part of the colon does colorectal carcinoma most commonly develop?
questions.solution:
In the colon, colorectal carcinoma most commonly develops in the sigmoid colon.

Overall, the most common site of colorectal carcinoma is the rectum.

The sites of development of colorectal carcinoma in order of frequency are:

  • Rectum 
  • Sigmoid colon
  • Caecum
  • Transverse colon
  • Ascending colon
  • Descending colon
  • Splenic flexure
  • Hepatic flexure

questions.text:
Which of the following are risk factors for colon carcinoma?
  1. Ulcerative colitis
  2. Cholecystectomy
  3. Smoking 
  4. Ureterosigmoidostomy 
  5. Previous colonic surgery
questions.solution:
Ulcerative colitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), cholecystectomy, ureterosigmoidostomy, and smoking are risk factors for colon cancer.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Colorectal Cancer

The risk factors for colorectal cancer are:

  • Dietary:
    • High-animal-fat diet
    • Low-fiber diet
    • Alcohol
  • Hereditary syndromes:
    • FAP
    • HNPCC
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Cholecystectomy: increased right colon cancer due to exposure to bile acids
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • Smoking
  • Acromegaly
  • Pelvic irradiation

questions.text: Which of the following dietary recommendation puts patients at risk of developing colon cancer?
questions.solution:
High-calorie, low-fiber, and high-animal-fat diet as well as alcohol consumption increase the risk of colon cancer.

Calcium, selenium, vitamins A, C, and E, carotenoids, and plant phenols are protective.

Implication of low-fiber diet as a risk factor for colon carcinoma is unclear with different cohort and case–control studies giving conflicting findings. Hence, option A has been changed from low-fiber diet  to high-caloric diet as a risk factor.

questions.text: Which of the following colonoscopic findings has the highest risk of developing colorectal cancer?
questions.solution:
Sessile/flat polyps are at a higher risk of malignancy compared to pedunculated polyps. Multiple polyps increase the risk of malignancy. 

The probability of development of malignancy of a polyp depends on the following:

  • Gross appearance of lesion: Sessile polyps are at higher risk for malignancy than pedunculated tumors.
  • Histology: Villous > Tubulovillous > tubular
  • Size: Polyps of size >2 cm are at higher risk.

questions.text: Mutations in which gene is responsible for malignant changes in late colonic adenomas?
questions.solution:
p53 mutation is responsible for the transformation of late adenoma to carcinoma.

The earliest mutations in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence occur in the APC gene and the earliest phenotypic change is known as aberrant crypt formation.

The most consistent genetic aberrations within these cells abnormally result in the formation of short pro­teins known as APC truncations. They occur in the mutational cluster region of the gene, an area responsible for β-catenin binding.

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text:
Which of the following is the correctly matched set regarding risk category and colon cancer screening recommendation?
Risk category Colonoscopy screening

1. Patients at average risk

 A. every 3-5 yearly, starting at age 35 yrs

2. Lynch syndrome

 B. every 1-2 yearly, starting 8 years after diagnosis

3. Inflammatory bowel disease

 C. every 10 years, starting at age 50 yrs

4. Father diagnosed with colorectal cancer at age 45 years

 D. every 1-2 years, starting at age 20-25 years
questions.solution:
Option A states the correctly matched pairs regarding risk category and colon cancer screening recommendation.

Current recommendation on colon cancer screening
Risk category Recommendation
Patients at average risk General population Colonoscopy every 10 years between 50 -75 years
Patients at higher risk Diagnosis of colon cancer or adenomatous polyps in
  • Any first-degree relative at age <60 years
  • ≥2 first-degree relatives at age ≥60 years
 Colonoscopy every 3-5 years starting at whichever comes first
  • age 40 or 
  • at least 10 years before the relative’s age of diagnosis
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis) Colonoscopy every 1-2 years starting 8 years after diagnosis
Familial adenomatous polyposis Colonoscopy every year starting at the age of 10-12 years
Lynch syndrome (HNPCC) Colonoscopy every 1-2 years starting at 20-25 years

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. He has conjunctival pallor and has lost significant weight over 3 months. A CBC reveals low haemoglobin and MCV. A stool occult blood test is positive. What is the next best step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with sudden onset anemia always warrants screening for colorectal cancer, as cancers in the right colon often manifest as melena and fatigue associated with anemia. Thus, the next best investigation is a colonoscopy.

Colonoscopy is the investigation of choice & gold standard for establishing the diag­nosis of colon cancer.

It permits biopsy of the tumor to verify the diagnosis while allowing inspection of the entire colon to exclude metachronous polyps or cancers.

Colonoscopy is generally performed even after cancer is detected by barium enema, in order to obtain a biopsy specimen and to detect (and remove) small polyps that may have been missed in the contrast study.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and constipation. A barium enema reveals an apple core sign. In which part of the colon is such a growth commonly seen?
questions.solution:
Apple core sign on barium enema is suggestive of a constricting type of colon cancer that is more common on the left side. Ulcerative type is more common on the right side.

Most patients with left-sided colon cancers often present with increasing constipation while patients with right-sided colon cancer often present with melena and fatigue associated with anemia.

The apple core sign describes a short segment irregular circumferential stricture of the large bowel that has abrupt shouldered margins resembling an apple core.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting feature in patients with right sided colon cancer ?
questions.solution:
Anemia is the most common presenting feature in patients with right-sided colon cancer.

Cancers in the right colon are more often manifested as melena, fatigue associated with anemia, or abdominal pain (if the tumor is advanced).

Cancer of the left colon mainly presents with altered bowel habits, usually constipation and intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false about virtual colonoscopy as compared to conventional colonoscopy?

choices.text: Virtual colonoscopy is less sensitive for small polyps
Provids a better image than conventional colonoscopy
Easier to take tissue biopsy during virtual colonoscopy
Less time consuming than conventional colonoscopy

questions.solution:
Virtual colonoscopy is a non-invasive technique and is not useful in taking biopsy.

Related Pearl: Virtual/CT Colonoscopy

CT colonography (virtual colonoscopy)

It uses helical CT and three-dimensional reconstruction to detect intraluminal colonic lesions.

Oral bowel preparation, oral and rectal contrast, and colon insufflation have been used to maximize sensitivity.

Advantages:

  • Noninvasive, less time consuming
  • Sensitivity may be as good as colonoscopy

Disadvantages:

  • Requires bowel preparation
  • Insensitive for small polyps
  • Minimal experience and data
  • Colonoscopy required for positive result

False positive results from retained stool, diverticular disease, haustral folds, motion artifacts, and an inability to detect flat adenomas.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with low-grade fever, easy fatiguability, and pain in the right hypochondrium. On examination, pallor and moderate hepatomegaly were present. A CT scan revealed non-enhancing masses. The biopsy showed adenocarcinoma, not of hepatic origin. A combination of IHC tests was done and was reported as CK 7 (-), CK20 (+). Which of the following is the most likely primary site of origin?
questions.solution:
Colorectal carcinoma is the most likely primary tumor for the given metastases. Among the given options, cytokeratin 7 is negative only in colon carcinoma.

The most common site of distant metastasis from colorectal cancer is the liver. These metastases arise from hematogenous spread via the portal venous system.The lung is the next most common site for metastasis.

Cytokeratin profiles of various primary tumors:

 

CK 7 positive

CK20 positive
  • Cholangiocarcinoma
  • Ovarian mucinous carcinoma

CK 7 positive 

CK 20 negative
  • Breast carcinoma
  • Ovarian serous adenocarcinoma
  • Thyroid carcinoma
  • Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
  • Lung carcinoma

CK 7 negative

CK 20 positive
  • Colorectal adenocarcinoma
  • Merkel cell carcinoma

CK 7 negative

CK 20 negative
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Prostatic adenocarcinoma
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: What is the most important prognostic factor in patients with colorectal carcinoma?
questions.solution: The most important determinant of prognosis for colorectal carcinoma is the tumour stage and, in particular, lymph node status. The T-stage (depth of invasion) is the single most significant predictor of lymph node spread.

questions.text:
Choose the parameters used to stage colorectal carcinoma according to Duke's classification ?

1. Lymph node involvement

2. Site of the tumor

3. Size of the tumor 

4. Depth of the tumor

5. Age of the patient
questions.solution:
Duke’s classification is based on the depth of tumor and lymph node status.

Related Pearl: Dukes’ staging for colorectal cancer

  • Stage A - Invasion of but not breaching the muscularis propria
  • Stage B - Breaching the muscularis propria but not involving lymph nodes
  • Stage C - Lymph nodes involved

Dukes himself never described a stage D, but this is often used to describe metastatic disease

questions.text: The biopsy of a hemicolectomy specimen revealed an adenocarcinoma with colonic subserosa invasion. Deposits were found on the mesentery but lymph nodes were not involved. Further investigation on the patient did not indicate local or distant metastases. What is the stage of the tumor ?
questions.solution:
According to 8th American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) classification of colorectal cancers, tumor deposits in the subserosa or mesentery are staged as N1c and tumor invading the subserosa without involvement of peritonealized organs is T3. 

TNM staging 7th AJCC (2010) 8th AJCC (2018)
Primary tumor(pT)    
TX Cannot be assessed -do-
T0 No evidence of cancer -do-
Tis Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ, intramucosal carcinoma (involvement of lamina propria with no extension through muscularis mucosae)
T1 invades submucosa -do-
T2 invades muscularis propria -do-
T3 invades muscularis propria into subserosa or into nonperitonealized pericolic or perirectal tissues -do-
T4 invades other organs or tissues or perforates the visceral peritoneum of specimen

T4a: invades through visceral peritoneum (including gross perforation of the bowel and invasion of tumor through areas of inflammation to the surface of the visceral peritoneum)

T4b: invades or adheres to other adjacent organs or structures
Regional lymph nodes (pN)
NX Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed -do-

N2b:  >7 regional lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (pM)

M1b: metastasis to >2 sites or organs is identified without peritoneal metastasis

questions.text:
Match the following patients with colon cancer to the procedure that is best suited.
Patient Procedure
1. A frail 82-year-old patient with the inability to pass stool and flatus A.Hartmann's Procedure
2. A 56-year-old patient with stable vitals and a distended bowel with increased, high-pitched bowel sounds. B.Stent placement via a colonoscope
3. A 63-year-old patient with vomiting and a rigid, tender abdomen. An X-Ray shows a single level obstruction C.Resection and primary anastomosis
questions.solution:
All of the given procedures may be performed in a patient with colonic cancer presenting with features of left colonic obstruction. The most appropriate answer is 1-B,2-C,3-A.

In Hartmann's procedure, the segment of the colon containing the obstructing cancer is resected and closure of the distal sigmoid or rectum is performed. A colostomy is made. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colos­tomy and fashioning a colorectal anastomosis.

This procedure is preferred in patients when a resection and primary anastomosis cannot be performed immediately due to complications such as inflammation of the bowel, perforation, or peritonitis.

Resection and primary anastomosis is done in patients who are hemody­namically stable and have pliable, nonedematous, well-vascularized bowel. 

In this procedure, the segment of the left colon containing the cancer is resected. The remain­ing colon is cleaned with saline lavage by inserting a catheter through the appendix or ileum into the cecum and irrigating the contents from the colon. Primary anastomosis between the prepared colon and rectum is fashioned subsequently, without the need for a temporary colostomy 

Stent placement via colonoscope is a temporary measure to obtain time for bowel preparation for primary anastomosis. A stent that traverses the tumor is placed to relieve the obstruction. It is done in partial obstruction and is preferred in old and frail patients.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was rushed to the ER with abdominal pain, obstipation, and altered mental status for the last 2 days. Physical examination and imaging findings are suggestive of perforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis. After stabilization, he is immediately taken to the operating room, where a suspicious ascending colon mass is seen. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The elderly man with ascending colon mass leading to perforated intestinal obstruction with peritonitis should ideally be treated with right hemicolectomy and ileocolostomy.

In case of suspected colorectal cancer presenting with intestinal obstruction the following surgeries are done:

  • Right-sided lesion: 
    • A resection (right hemicolectomy) and anastomosis if the patient is stable 
    • Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: right hemicolectomy + ileocolostomy
  • Left-sided lesion: 
    • Resection and anastomosis if the patient is stable
    • Perforation with substantial contamination or if the patient is unstable: Hartmann procedure is done. Later, intestinal continuity is re-established by the closure of the colos­tomy and fashioning a colorectal anastomosis.
    • Where endoscopic and radiological facilities are present an obstructing left-sided lesion can be treated with an expanding metal stent provided bowel perforation is absent.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with stage II colorectal carcinoma located in the transverse colon. Which of the following is the surgical procedure of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Extended right hemicolectomy is the most appropriate surgical procedure for a neoplastic tumor in the transverse colon. This procedure involves resection of the 

  • Terminal ileum with Ileocecal junction
  • Cecum
  • Ascending colon
  • Hepatic flexure, and
  • Distal transverse colon

Very small and localized lesions in the transverse colon may be resected by transverse colectomy. However, this procedure is very uncommon.

Tumor location Procedure of choice Resected bowel segments
Cecum / Ascending colon / Hepatic flexure Right hemicolectomy
  • Terminal ileum with Ileocecal junction
  • Cecum
  • Ascending colon
  • Hepatic flexure
Transverse colon / Hepatic flexure Extended right hemicolectomy
  • Terminal ileum with Ileocecal junction
  • Cecum
  • Ascending colon
  • Hepatic flexure
  • Distal transverse colon 
  • Splenic flexure may be resected based on the tumor location
Descending colon ± sigmoid colon Left hemicolectomy
  • Transverse colon(left MCA territory)
  • Splenic flexure
  • Descending colon upto sigmoid colon
Sigmoid colon Sigmoid colectomy, or LAR (Low anterior resection)
  • Entire sigmoid colon and rectum is removed
  • Coloanal anastomosis is performed

questions.text: A male patient presented with dull abdominal pain and rectal bleeding. On investigations, he was diagnosed with colon carcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of colorectal carcinoma?

choices.text: Stage III cancer is treated with surgical resection and chemotherapy
Stage II cancer with young age is an indication for chemotherapy
FOLFOX regimen is used for colorectal carcinoma
Immunotherapy is ineffective in metastatic colorectal carcinoma

questions.solution:
Immunotherapy is not ineffective in metastatic colorectal cancer. Metastatic or recurrent colorectal cancers are the indications for immunotherapy.

Monoclonal antibodies such as

  • Bevacizumab (Anti-VEGF),
  • Cetuximab (anti-EGFR),
  • Panitumumab (anti-EGFR),
  • Pembrolizumab (anti-PDL1),
  • Nivolumab (anti-PDL), etc. are the commonly used immunotherapeutic drugs in colorectal carcinoma.

Option A: Surgical resection is indicated in all the stages of colon carcinoma. Management of Stage III colorectal carcinoma should also include chemotherapy, in addition to surgical resection. The stage-specific therapies are as follows:

Stage Management
Stage I:
  • Surgical resection
Stage II:
  • Surgical resection
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy in high-risk patients (presence of poor prognostic factors)
Stage III:
  • Surgical resection
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy (folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, oxaliplatin)
Stage IV:
  • Surgical resection with adjuvant chemotherapy
  • Radiotherapy
  • Immunotherapy (monoclonal antibodies)
  • Palliative treatment in extensive metastasis. 

 

Option B: Stage II cancer in young patients should be considered for chemotherapy. Treatment of stage II colon carcinoma is surgical resection of the cancerous mass. Adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated in patients with at least one poor prognostic indicator like:

  • Young patients
  • Inadequate lymph node excision(<12 lymph nodes)
  • Poorly differentiated histology
  • Positive margin of resection
  • T4 lesions
  • Bowel obstruction or perforation
  • Presence of perineural or lymphovascular invasion

Option C: FOLFOX is a chemotherapy regimen used for the treatment of colorectal cancer, made up of the drugs folinic acid, 5-fluorouracil, and oxaliplatin.

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding different types of artificial stoma?

choices.text: Output from an ileostomy is liquid in nature
In Hartmann procedure, a loop colostomy is formed
Skin excoriation is the most common complication of ileostomy
Parastomal herniation is more common in Loop colostomy

questions.solution:
Colostomy formed during the Hartmann procedure is not a loop colostomy. It is an example of end-colostomy.

Artificial stomas are surgically created openings on the abdominal wall following certain types of surgeries, to serve as an alternate path for internal organs to drain externally. Ileostomy and colostomy are the two most common types of artificial stomas for the GI system.

Ileostomy Colostomy
Any portion of the entire ileum can be chosen for stoma creation Only mobile parts of the colon (transverse colon and sigmoid colon) can be used
Gross appearance - margin of the stoma is elevated (pouting) from the skin  Gross appearance - at the same level as that of skin
The output is liquid in nature and therefore higher in volume The output is semi-solid or solid in nature
Higher chance of skin excoriation and electrolyte imbalance Easier to handle

Based on the structural pattern, stomas can be classified into different types:

  • End stoma
  • Loop stoma
  • Double barrel stoma

End stoma is preferred as a permanent stoma. Loop and double barrel stomas are used as temporary stomas.

Complications of stoma include

  • Skin excoriation (most common)
  • Stoma infection
  • Diarrhea
  • Stoma leakage
  • Parastomal herniation
